results.text: i wanna know whats the most used port hacking tool?
I wanna know what you think "port hacking" is?

Ports serve as entry points for communication between devices and are associated with specific services or protocols, such as HTTP port 80 or SSH port 22. When improperly secured, these ports can become an attack
Sure, but what is "port hacking"?
There's port scanning... there's attacks on specific services...
refers to the act of exploiting vulnerabilities or weaknesses

regardless, back to your original question now that I know what you're asking: There isn't a single specific tool that gets used for exploiting vulnerabilities. Probably the closest thing to a universal tool would be Metasploit, but that might only help you with 20% of the vulnerabilities out there...

For example if you want to write an exploit that takes advantage of a buffer overflow, you need to understand how the system works at a low level, and be able to set up and make syscalls directly from binary shellcode
It is also going to be important for malware development if you want to write something that attempts to properly bypass detection (not just silly Python malware)
Also Grey Hat Hacking, latest edition
It's a solid read still for binary exploitation

https://faq.hackncode.dev/from-power-button-to-pwn-a-roadmap-to-computer-security/

The other thing you mentioned is "commen vulns that no one uses in real life scenarios". The thing to understand is that the vast majority of the time, people fail at the most basic levels of security. You might think that something like a directory traversal, or a basic SQLi, or even a default password is something silly that you will never see in the real world, but you'd be shocked how often those are seen in the wild
It's not critical knowledge to have for ethical hacking, but to be honest, if you really want to get into the world of cybersecurity you should start exercising your learning skills

Crafting a CSRF Attack: Crafting a CSRF attack typically involves creating HTML that triggers an HTTP request to the target website. Common methods include: * tags: These can be used for GET requests that might change data on the server. For example: If the bank's transfer function uses a simple GET request without proper CSRF protection, visiting the evil-hacker.com page could unknowingly trigger this tr

of how the web works – allowing different websites to link to and interact with each other.
The vulnerability lies in the target website (legit-bank.com) not being able to distinguish between a legitimate request originating from its own forms and a malicious request triggered by a third-party site, because both carry the same valid session cookie.
Defense Mechanisms:
Modern web frameworks and security best practices employ various techniques to prevent CSRF attacks. The most common is the use

e user's session on legit-bank.com, it cannot know or include the correct CSRF token in its forged request. This prevents the attack.
Other defense mechanisms include:
 * SameSite Cookies: This browser security feature allows developers to control whether cookies are sent along with cross-site requests. Setting the SameSite attribute to Strict or Lax can significantly reduce the risk of CSRF.

Hi everyone,

I’m currently exploring the idea of running a game server and wanted to include some kind of HWID protection to improve security. I purchased a pre-built system and integrated it into the game, but since I only have usage rights and not the source code, I’ve been doing a series of tests to better understand how it actually works.

I’ve simulated different scenarios — even wrote a few basic drivers — to see how the protection responds. While I was able to bypass certain versions of

it, there’s one specific layer I haven’t been able to overcome yet.

I’m doing this not just out of curiosity, but because I want to fully understand the protection mechanism in order to modify and adapt it for my own server setup.

If anyone here has experience with reverse engineering or analyzing protection systems, I’d really appreciate any tips, tools, or general guidance you could offer.

Thanks in advance!

`HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography\MachineGuid` spoofable with `sysprep`
`HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\ProductId`
`HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\DigitalProductId`
These are also often usded for fingerprinting devices

Guys, I am trying to hack a device that I have installed in VMware using Kali Linux, but how do I hack the https system easily?
Theres a lot to unpack there. Are you hosting an intentionally vulnerable service that you can access? Do you know what vulns you would be testing for?

Look, I have two systems installed on VMware Workstation Pro, Kali and Windows, and I saw a clip that he was able to decrypt HTTPS with Bettercap using hstshijack/hstshijack, and I tried to do the same, but unfortunately, HTTPS was not decrypted
It is super easy to decrypt https traffic, you just need a break and inspect setup
In the case of an attack in the lab you’d need to intercept the handshakes and send alternate certificates @R
Some security products hook into the TCP/IP stack so they can view things like this
This is a whole different can of worms, and there is a large part of the security world that actively thinks this is harmful

But yes, I can confirm that done properly, a trusted party can run an HTTPS MITM attack and the user will have no idea. I have this set up in my homelab to investigate android apps to see what traffic they send

from chatGPT:
```
Good question — I’ll answer carefully and responsibly.

People who create or spread trojans are usually doing malicious things, because trojans are a type of malware. Some common (illegal) uses include:

Stealing data (passwords, credit card numbers, personal files).

Remote access (allowing attackers to control the victim’s computer).

Installing more malware (like ransomware or cryptominers).

Using the victim’s computer in botnets (for spam or DDoS attacks).

Surveillance (l

ogging keystrokes, activating webcams, etc.).

⚠️ Important: Using or distributing trojans without permission is cybercrime.

On the defensive side, security researchers and penetration testers may study trojans in a controlled environment to:

Learn how they work (reverse engineering).

Improve antivirus / endpoint detection.

Test defenses in red team exercises.

So the legit, ethical use is for research, education, and improving defenses — but in the wild, criminals mainly use them for theft,

spying, and sabotage.

👉 Do you want me to give you a defensive perspective (like how to detect and protect against trojans), or more of a research perspective (like how analysts study them)?
```

My advice to you would be: It sounds like you have a genuine interest in cybersecurity. If you don't get this specific internship, there will be others in the future. A network-enabled attack is an attack that either:
    1.    Exploits vulnerabilities in network protocols, services, or configurations, or
    2.    Uses network connectivity as a vector to deliver, coordinate, or propagate the attack.
